column4: once i have them there's no software to use em with, so I'll pass
not sure about "unix based" but there's gpsdrive and a couple of others you can use in ubuntu
gpsdrive can use maps from different sources.. openstreetmap or similar and others
ah, but I thought gpsdrive just gave you an arrow (eg the azimuth of where you're supposed to be going) instead of "turn left in 300m" type navigation
I guess you could sort-of do that by asking Google maps and then extracting the data as a gpx file?
ahh.. that's true... it only uses the map as a background.. it can't tell roads from fields/sea and such.. those maps cost money.. lots of money
yeah, I know
unfortunately tomtom doesn't hand out their software yet
which is stupid since the tomtom one/go navigation things are just linux boxes
not sure if they will do something when/if openstreetmap takes off.. but that's still pretty unfinished
well.. if that software were available to everyone we wouldn't be buying tomtom-boxes, now would we? =)
who cares about the software
the maps is where the money is
you get the software for free now too, there's no way there's only 60 euros worth of hardware in those things
yes.. change software to software/maps
i have no problem with paying for maps
they cost money to make, it's only fair to pay back their R&D costs
there are maps you can buy.. at least in sweden there are some from the swedish institude responsible for measuring the county.. but those cost up to 1000 USD.. that's a bit steep imho
